title: How to Remove Mold from Bags

methods.name: Using a Toothbrush to Spot Clean

steps.headline: Mix a mild detergent with water if you're cleaning a leather bag.
steps.description: Fill a bowl with water and squirt dish soap or hand soap into the water. Stir the water and soap together until soap bubbles form. You can use as much or as little soap as you’d like, but using roughly 1 US tbsp (15 ml) of dish or hand soap should work well.

steps.headline: Form a paste using baking soda to kill mold on fabric or synthetic bags.
steps.description: Pour clean water into a small bowl before adding baking soda to the water in small increments. Add a spoonful at a time, mixing it together thoroughly. Once you’ve created a paste, your mixture is ready to be used. It’s best for the paste to be more watery than solid to make spreading it onto the bag easier.

steps.headline: Use vinegar as a natural disinfectant for bags made of any material.
steps.description: Dilute the vinegar by using 1 part vinegar and 1 part water, or use pure white vinegar as a stronger cleaner. Mix the water and vinegar in a bowl to get it ready for use. To dilute the vinegar even more, use 1 part white vinegar and 2 parts water. This works well on leather and canvas, as well as things made of synthetic materials like backpacks.

steps.headline: Dip an old toothbrush in your chosen cleaning liquid to start removing the mold.
steps.description: Regardless of whether you're using dish soap, baking soda, or vinegar, find an old toothbrush around the house to use to clean the mold off of your bag. Dip the toothbrush in your chosen cleaning liquid once it’s properly mixed. Tap the toothbrush on the edge of the bowl to prevent it from dripping, if desired. If you don’t have an old toothbrush to use, purchase a cheap new one or use a clean cloth instead.

steps.headline: Use the toothbrush to scrub the mold off of the bag.
steps.description: Scrub the mold in circles with the toothbrush, creating a lather if your cleaning mixture contains soap. Dip your toothbrush back in the liquid after you clean one section to remove the mold from the toothbrush and apply more cleaner. Scrub the bag using the toothbrush until the mold is completely gone. Clean the entire surface of the bag to make sure you get rid of any possible mold spores.

steps.headline: Wet a cloth with water to wipe the cleaning liquid off.
steps.description: Dampen a washcloth or microfiber towel with water, squeezing it out gently to remove excess moisture. Swipe the cloth over each cleaned section of your bag to get rid of the extra cleaner that’s still on the bag. Rinse out your cloth and re-wet it after every couple of swipes to make sure you’re not putting cleaning liquid back onto the bag.

steps.headline: Flip your bag inside out to clean the interior as well.
steps.description: If there’s dirt or mold inside of your bag, or you just want to give it a cleaning too, flip it inside out if possible. If you can't flip it inside out, simply open it up as far as it will go and clean it with the toothbrush just like you did the exterior. Wipe the interior of the bag with a damp cloth to get rid of any excess cleaning solution.

methods.name: Cleaning Machine-Washable Bags in Hot Water

steps.headline: Wash canvas, cotton, and bags made from synthetic materials in the washing machine or by hand.
steps.description: These materials can often be submerged completely in water, making it easier to clean them. Look at the tag on your bag that says what it's made out of, as well as how to wash it. If it says it's okay to wash in hot water and can be submerged, it's fine to put in the washing machine. If your bag says hand wash only, you'll need to hand wash it in water yourself or spot treat it.

steps.headline: Set your washing machine on a hot water cycle and add detergent.
steps.description: If it's okay for your bag to be fully submerged in water, place your bag in the washing machine and choose a hot water setting. Measure out your laundry detergent according to its specific cup measurement (though it's not necessary to use a full load's worth of detergent since you're just washing the bag). The hot water will help sanitize and kill the mold. If it's possible to put your washing machine on delicate while using hot water, this is a good option to help ensure your bag isn't damaged. Skip the detergent if you're worried about damaging your bag and just sanitize it in the hot water.

steps.headline: Hand wash the bag in hot water for a more delicate option.
steps.description: Fill a basin with hot water and soak your bag in it, rubbing the mold off with a scrub brush or sponge. Rinse the bag with clean hot water once you've removed all of the mold to help sanitize and clean it fully. While the water should be hot, it shouldn’t be close to boiling. Water that’s too hot may damage your bag.

methods.name: Drying the Bag and Preventing Mold

steps.headline: Dab the bag with a dry towel to absorb the excess moisture.
steps.description: Use a clean towel to blot the bag, pressing down on each section to absorb as much water as possible. If your towel starts getting too damp, use a new one that’s completely dry.

steps.headline: Set the bag outdoors so it can dry in the sunlight.
steps.description: Lay the bag out in the sunlight on a towel or hang it on a hanger. Leave it out in the sun for 1-3 hours, opening it up so the inside can dry too if it was also wet. Avoid leaving leather bags out in the sun for more than 2 hours so the leather doesn’t dry and crack. After a couple hours, move the bag into the shade and leave it there for a while longer to continue drying in the fresh air.

steps.headline: Apply a leather conditioner if your bag is made of leather.
steps.description: Squeeze a small amount of leather conditioner onto a clean microfiber rag, according to the specific leather conditioner’s instructions. Apply the leather conditioner using small circle motions, covering the entire leather bag evenly. Wipe off any excess leather conditioner so the surface is clean and smooth. The leather conditioner will add moisture back into the leather to keep it healthy.

steps.headline: Keep your bag away from humidity to avoid growing mold.
steps.description: Mold loves humid, moist spots, and if your bags are kept in an area like this, they're likely to grow mold. Store your bags in an area with good ventilation that stays dry. Consider storing your bags in a breathable bag as opposed to a plastic one. If your home is naturally more humid, consider getting a dehumidifier for the area where your bags are stored.

steps.headline: Check your bags every month or so to make sure mold hasn't grown.
steps.description: Mold can grow quickly, so it's important to find it before it spreads and is too difficult to clean. If you store your bags in a box or on a shelf, take them out every month or so to check them for mold, looking at the inside of the bag as well as the outside. As an extra precaution, leave your bags out in the sunlight for an hour to help kill off potential mold and provide fresh air.

Stir the water and soap together until soap bubbles form. You can use as much or as little soap as you’d like, but using roughly 1 US tbsp (15 ml) of dish or hand soap should work well. Form a paste using baking soda to kill mold on fabric or synthetic bags. Pour clean water into a small bowl before adding baking soda to the water in small increments. Dilute the vinegar by using 1 part vinegar and 1 part water, or use pure white vinegar as a stronger cleaner. Mix the water and vinegar in a bowl to get it ready for use. To dilute the vinegar even more, use 1 part white vinegar and 2 parts water. This works well on leather and canvas, as well as things made of synthetic materials like backpacks. Dip an old toothbrush in your chosen cleaning liquid to start removing the mold. Regardless of whether you're using dish soap, baking soda, or vinegar, find an old toothbrush around the house to use to clean the mold off of your bag. Dip the toothbrush in your chosen cleaning liquid once it’s properly mixed. Tap the toothbrush on the edge of the bowl to prevent it from dripping, if desired. If you don’t have an old toothbrush to use, purchase a cheap new one or use a clean cloth instead. Use the toothbrush to scrub the mold off of the bag. These materials can often be submerged completely in water, making it easier to clean them. Look at the tag on your bag that says what it's made out of, as well as how to wash it. If it says it's okay to wash in hot water and can be submerged, it's fine to put in the washing machine. If your bag says hand wash only, you'll need to hand wash it in water yourself or spot treat it. Set your washing machine on a hot water cycle and add detergent. If it's okay for your bag to be fully submerged in water, place your bag in the washing machine and choose a hot water setting. Measure out your laundry detergent according to its specific cup measurement (though it's not necessary to use a full load's worth of detergent since you're just washing the bag). The hot water will help sanitize and kill the mold. If it's possible to put your washing machine on delicate while using hot water, this is a good option to help ensure your bag isn't damaged. Skip the detergent if you're worried about damaging your bag and just sanitize it in the hot water. Hand wash the bag in hot water for a more delicate option. Fill a basin with hot water and soak your bag in it, rubbing the mold off with a scrub brush or sponge. Rinse the bag with clean hot water once you've removed all of the mold to help sanitize and clean it fully. While the water should be hot, it shouldn’t be close to boiling. Water that’s too hot may damage your bag. Drying the Bag and Preventing Mold Dab the bag with a dry towel to absorb the excess moisture. Use a clean towel to blot the bag, pressing down on each section to absorb as much water as possible. If your towel starts getting too damp, use a new one that’s completely dry. Set the bag outdoors so it can dry in the sunlight. Lay the bag out in the sunlight on a towel or hang it on a hanger. The leather conditioner will add moisture back into the leather to keep it healthy. Keep your bag away from humidity to avoid growing mold. Mold loves humid, moist spots, and if your bags are kept in an area like this, they're likely to grow mold. Store your bags in an area with good ventilation that stays dry. Consider storing your bags in a breathable bag as opposed to a plastic one. If your home is naturally more humid, consider getting a dehumidifier for the area where your bags are stored. Check your bags every month or so to make sure mold hasn't grown. Mold can grow quickly, so it's important to find it before it spreads and is too difficult to clean. If you store your bags in a box or on a shelf, take them out every month or so to check them for mold, looking at the inside of the bag as well as the outside. As an extra precaution, leave your bags out in the sunlight for an hour to help kill off potential mold and provide fresh air.
